And so the equilibrium is that the system gets "captured" by one "political party" that bribes everyone and engages in some combination of parasite-helping-the-host-survive and rent extraction, kind of like dictatorial governments.

Fundamentally, all DPOS systems as far as I can tell basically succumb to the explicit bribing attack. These pools give up to 90% of their staking revenues out to anyone who votes for them; this game inherently favors larger and larger pools
Note that "bribe" includes "vote for my candidate or you lose your job", "vote for my candidate or I won't be friends with you", etc etc.

Voting systems in the real world have a coercion-resistant secret ballot property because otherwise it's too easy to bribe a highly distributed voter set; voting honestly is a tragedy of the commons problem.
